author: 8BrickMario
title: Assimilate him into your collection!
review:
When Doctor Who was announced for Dimensions, excitement abounded over what they might do, and we now have two of the show's most famous villains, and the only ones who could be logically playable. 

Box/Instructions

The art here is pretty nice, with the dishonestly shiny Cyberman on the front in a facility filled with inactive Cybermen. 

Parts

The parts here are slightly less interesting, but I think the dark tan wedge plates and the Dalek dome are nice.

Minifigures

The Cyberman is the minifigure you get here, and he's great. Based on the modern post-revival design, the figure captures the trademark look of the Cybermen, with their handlebar heads and the tear-like eye design. The plated armor of the body is generic enough to be used in multiple places, most notably, Iron Man figures, due to the arc-reactor-like core. The minifigure is entirely pearl silver, which is fine, and the head, of course, is a new mold. 

The build

The build was pretty simple, with some basic SNOT techniques used for the Dalek's plating. 

The completed model

The Dalek serves its purpose, looking like the Doctor's most famous and numerous enemies. The exposed studs of a LEGO plate capture the knobs on a Dalek's sides rather nicely, and the sloping front has been achieved well. However, the black rim on the base is less than satisfatory, with the Ideas model capturing it slightly better. A nice unintentional feature of the Dalek is that its head can be removed pretty easily, and a minifigure torso can be placed where it was, a la Davros.  

Gameplay

The Cyberman is one of those characters you need to  buy for completion, but only for minor reasons, like a puzzle or two only possible with that one character. His abilities include explosive shots that destroy silver LEGO, using control panels and hacking blue terminals, and diving underwater. There's at least one underwater terminal guarded by silver, so good luck solving that! The main draw for me, though, was the drone ability which he shares with Doc Brown. In the Cyberman's case, he'll summon a Cybermat from the ground, which can move independently in a large range and can collect items. Leaving the range or switching out of drone mode will cause it to fall apart. The main purpose, though, is to navigate blue tube mazes, which will usually lead to a switch that opens a chest containing a Gold Brick. The Cyberman and Doc are currently the only characters with drones, and I think this one is much more useful.

The Dalek, however, is a bit disappointing if you wanted a character, for, like the Sentry Turret, it has been stripped of its personality and is only treated as a nonsentient vehicle. While you could argue that it was hijacked and the pilot inside removed, it still feels a bit odd to be hitching a ride on a silent Dalek. Its blasts are also explosive, and it can be upgraded to some atrocious-looking models which will grant further abilities like gold destruction.

While I've already discussed it in my Doctor Who Level Pack review, owning the Cyberman will allow you to access the Doctor Who world. 

Overall opinion

I think this is a great Fun Pack to have. The minifigure is fantastic, and the gameplay is greatly enhanced by using him. I'd recommend it!

author: ThoughtLash
title: "This is not war - this is pest control!" -Dalek Sec
review:
I picked this up on sale today, due to being a very big Doctor Who fan. I don't even have Dimensions, I just wanted a Dalek model and a Cyberman!

Box/Instructions

The set came in a cardboard package, an oddly-shaped affair that can be opened along the side. It features a closeup of a Cyberman, with an army of the Mondasian cyborgs in the background.

The instructions are quite lame, really. They show only how to build the Cyberman and how to use him in the game, the Dalek must either be found online or in the game. The remaining half of the thin booklet is a checklist for the other Dimensions sets.

Parts

Most of the parts here are rather common, consisting of plates and bricks with studs on the sides. Seven of the parts are in sand yellow, while the remaining few are black, tan, trans-blue, or silver, for the Cyberman. A printed sand yellow dish is included for use as the Dalek's dome. It is printed with the mount for the eyestalk and the two small lights on the top, which flash when the Dalek speaks.

The Cyberman uses an entirely new head sculpt, representing a Mondas Cyberman from the latter part of the new series. These are found from Nigthmare in Silver to Dark Water/Death in Heaven to Hell Bent. While I prefer both the Cybus and 80's Cybermen, this looks excellent. His body is also printed with an armored pattern, showing the armor plates and glowing light in the chest.

Two trans-light blue stands are also included, for use in the game. As I don't have the game, I don't know how well they work. The Dalek's is unprinted and features four studs, while the Cyberman's has a design resembling a Cyberman's chest and has only two studs.

Minifigures

The Cyberman looks amazing! The printing is wonderful, looking the best that a LEGO version can. I love the detail that LEGO put into him, it's definatley superior to the Character Building version, which I also have.

While the Dalek is not counted as a minifigure, I will list it as one. It looks great, despite being rather oversized (Daleks should be eye-level or less, depending on the version). The sand yellow matches with the Time War Dalek casings quite well, although the tan sticks out a little. Studs are used as the trademark "Dalek Bumps" or "hemispheres," and a black joystick and torch are used as the plunger and gunstick, respectively.

The build

Assembly didn't take long at all, and the Dalek is actually quite simple, using a good bit of SNOT on the inside. The Cyberman was the same as building any other minifigure, legs-torso-head-base.

The completed model

See minifigures.

Overall opinion

I would definately recommend this set, although I would advise getting it on sale (personally, $15 seems a little steep for what is included). Highly recommended for Doctor Who fans!

author: Odeinoichus
title: There is Logic in What He Says.
review:
Set #71238 Cyberman Fun Pack: One of the best offerings from Series 1 was this fun little Battle Pack for Doctor Who which is great if you want the character in-game, but also great for buying multiples and troop building a little arm of LEGO Cybermen and Daleks. It compliments the Ideas set quite nicely and I would go so far as to say that getting several of them would make for an excellent idea. It’s the only LEGO Dimensions I would recommend buying multiples of for the purposes of getting the Minifigure and Character Build alone and here is why.

Packaging

The image on the front shows the contents of the set and also shows a nice stylized version of the digital model of the Cyberman, then it shows an army of them in the background. A great image showcasing how this Minifigure would look in row upon row of multiples.

Parts

The parts in this set are pretty simple, they had not yet created the unique elements that the Ideas set used for the Dalek build so this version uses the likes of telescope and control level elements. The only thing unique here is the round radar dish element with the print on for the top of the Dalek’s domed head.

Minifigures

Cyberman: Introducing a new head element this Minifigure looks brilliant, it features some very detailed printing on both the torso and legs, but no arm printing, LEGO did a truly remarkable job in capturing the likeness of the creature from Doctor Who. Sadly it does not come with any accessory, so we don’t get the fancy new part they made for the Cybermat drones that are part of its digital abilities.

The build

The main build of the Dalek is a faithful depiction of the character as seen in-game, it is a build that works perfectly, the secondary models of the Fire ‘n Ride Dalek and the Silver Shooter Dalek are just really oddball ideas that I’m not sure are part of any actual Doctor Who lore, just something to do with the parts to make different models. I find myself avoiding them so instead of discussing them independently I’ve combined the build discussion for this set. Stick with the main build, it’s the best out of the three.

The completed model

Dalek: This model is somewhat different from the Ideas set, but still looks like a proper Dalek, the two models can be interpreted as different era Dalek’s if you’d prefer. It’s a rock solid model.

Fire ‘n Ride Dalek: This kind of looks like a vehicle model, and the Cyberman is shown riding it in-game. It’s a really awkward looking model that is not as iconic or as fun as the main build of the regular Dalek, but it is something different to build with the elements in this set if you’d prefer.

Silver Shooter Dalek: I suppose in the LEGO universe there could be very odd looking Daleks, perhaps for specialty functions. Hence why this and the secondary build exist in the LEGO world. I honestly just am not a fan of these re-builds, much like with the Tardis in the Doctor Who level pack the model of a plain ordinary Dalek works the best and these other models are just pointless.

The Digital Content

Adventure World: This is the second method of unlocking the Doctor Who adventure world, but you can’t access the level so if you only want one representation from each world for your collection you could potentially skip this, although the Cyberman is the only one who can do certain things under water which require his unique abilities.

Character & Toy Abilities: The Cyberman has Mind Control, Hacking, Drone Mazes, X-Ray Vision, Technology and the ability to Dive, he can also Destroy Silver LEGO Objects… as he is one of only a few characters capable of going underwater you definitely need him since he can do some things that others cannot.

The main Dalek build has no abilities, it’s just a toy you can ride around on for some fun. No attacks at all until you unlock that ability, but I suppose you can still ride around shouting EXTERMINATE as much as you want while riding them.

The Fire ‘n Ride Dalek is capable of Destroying Gold LEGO Objects and acts as a Rideable Turret, which is pretty fun. The Silver Shooter Dalek can Destroy Silver LEGO Objects and acts as a Flying Vehicle which means you can access Flight Docks and Flight Cargo Hooks. A solid selection of abilities.

Overall opinion

I believe the digital content is nice to have as a bonus, but buying multiples of this set for the build and Minifigure alone gives this a Highly Recommended from me. If you can find any at discount retailers or the like go for it, it’s a great little set to add to the Ideas set for more characters to populate the area surrounding the Tardis, for fans of the game it’s a very nice set to have too, so again Highly Recommended and have fun building an army.

author: Minifig290
title: Good Set Horrid Price
review:
This Review is based on the set ONLY and not based on anything in the game. This set was released in 2016 as part of Wave four in year one for the terrible price of £14.99.

Minifigure

The Cyberman is exclusive and uses a new and brilliant mold for his head that hasn't yet been re-printed. Its torso and leg print is very good and looks very similar to the detail seen on the BBC series villains. Its toy tag has a blue spot surrounded with the same type if print used on his torso.

Build

"Exterminate"  this build and you'll regret it, as it is fantastic and uses a printed dish on its head. Its torso is angled and the exposed studs look like the spots on the "real" robots. The Darlek sits on a toy tag that has a 2x2 round plate with a stud to keep the build on the tag.

Parts

For a set that only has 40 parts there are a few excellent pieces like all the parts for the Cyberman and the Darleks dish of which all are exclusive and the Cyberman's toy tag is unique to this set.

__________________________________________________________________________

Overall

Everything about this set is great apart from one thing and that is its hidiouse price, you only get 40 parts and your paying £15 meaning the price per part is stupidly high at 37.5p one of the highest ppp ever. Everything else about this set is great thought and it would make a great battle pack if it was only cheaper. So unless this set is cheap don't buy it unless you are a Doctor Who fan or Dimensions player.

Pros-  The Cyberman, Toy tags, Darlek and pieces

Cons- Price and Price Per Part
